Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 01:27PM nora_az wrote: Very normal Melinda....I was too numb to cry. In fact I have cried very little since the big bad radiologist scared the bejeezus out of me. Didnt cry when I got the word it was cancer, didnt cry after my oncology appointment to find out mine was triple positive and in one node, nothing. Just numbness. It would be healthier to cry and get it all out but it's normal to just be numb too.
Posts.Title: IDC - Histo grade 3; just waiting - forever Melinda_in_NC DanielleSurvivorSince03-09

Posts.Content: nora_az wrote: I know this may have been covered but I have looked all over for this topic and I must be blind or something  I will start chemo the day after Thanksgiving. Flu season coming up, colds all around here etc. I know after I start chemo it is very important for me to not get these common illnesses that normally hit in the Winter. Should I wear a mask when I go out in public during for these next 4 months?  I dont want to look like a hypochondriac but I also want to make sure I dont get sick. What did most of you do? DIEP with nipple sparing mastectomy on 10/13/10 TCH started 11/26/10 Anastrozole started 4/7/11 Hysterectomy/ooph and VATS (lung) surgery 5/22/12 diagnosis Coccidioidomycosis, not metastasis to the lungs as they thought. Yeahhh Dx 9/3/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: masks nora_az lago

Posts.Content: nora_az wrote: I had DIEP performed on October 13th at the Mayo in Phoenix. They used my tummy fat for immediate breast reconstruction.  I was so scared of the very long surgery and was a bundle of nerves beforehand for a good couple of weeks. They did find out that one lymph node was affected but other than that there were no other surprises in there. Very sore and cant do much for myself yet but I am looking down in awe of my flat tummy and perky looking breasts (I had a nipple sparing mastectomy as well)  Just wanted to return and report, I just wanted everyone to know that my surgery went very, very well and I am so impressed with the outcome. Next stop....chemo DIEP with nipple sparing mastectomy on 10/13/10 TCH started 11/26/10 Anastrozole started 4/7/11 Hysterectomy/ooph and VATS (lung) surgery 5/22/12 diagnosis Coccidioidomycosis, not metastasis to the lungs as they thought. Yeahhh Dx 9/3/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 06:25PM nora_az wrote: Hi EB Ann, My plastic surgeon at the Mayo was Dr Rebecca. I absolutely adore her. She is so down to earth and makes me feel as if anything i talk to her about is not bothering her. We have a very good patient/doctor report.   I had her last year for my breast reduction and knew she was the one I wanted for my DIEP. Dr Wasif is my oncologist at the Breast Clinic at Mayo. Yes, I would love to meet up with you girls. I am in the Surprise area. Nov 6th might be too soon, we will see. I am walking more everyday and feel as if I am healing fast, I just know it's going to take some time especially with these drains still in me  grrrrrrr
Posts.Title: Just home after DIEP nora_az nora_az

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 12:37PM nora_az wrote: My radiologist lacked bedside manner as well. I had went in to get an US/mammo because I had a lump. I was told to go to the inside waiting area after both were done and they would let me know when I could get dressed. 15 minutes later instead of telling me I could get dressed, the tech says, "Follow me" and I went to where the radiologist was. She started questioning me as to how long have I noticed this lump, she felt it was highly suspicious but wouldn't outright say the word "cancer" to me. It wasn't till I said, "I'm not too worried 90% of all lumps are benign"  did she smack me with, "Well, I'm telling you I am confident you are the 10%" did I realize she was telling me she felt I had cancer. I went in the next week for the biopsy.
Posts.Title: OK, need biopsy. Snarky radiologist, too. iammommy janet58

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 07:14AM nora_az wrote: bumping this one.....it's too good not too!  I hope all you girls are doing well today!
Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2012 07:56AM - edited Jun 24, 2012 07:57AM by nora_az In one surgical procedure a breast surgeon did a double mastectomy, it was nipple sparing so I still have that tissue. Then the plastic surgeon took over and she used my tummy fat to form new breasts. So I got a tummy tuck out of the deal. They use flaps from my abdomen and use it for new breasts. I went under with my own breasts and woke up with a tummy tuck and a "C" cup (I used to be "D") breasts that look very natural. It's a very hard surgery but so well worth it. There are only a handful of surgeons doing this.  I had mine done at the Mayo here in Phoenix.
Posts.Title: Preventive Double Mastectomy lisag46 lisag46

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2012 07:45AM nora_az wrote: I was 47 when I had my DIEP. That was almost 2 years ago. At the time I had a senior in high school and one in college.  Not really sure I'd want to not have no reconstruction especially at such a young age. That's what I liked about DIEP, very natural and no implants.
Posts.Title: Preventive Double Mastectomy lisag46 lisag46

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2012 07:39AM nora_az wrote: I actually had thought of this before I found out my diagnosis. I don't know, I had some sort of premonition I would get breast cancer based off family history. I had watched a documentary about women having a preventative double mastectomy and I was thinking it was a great idea. When I would even broach the subject with my husband or Mom I would get a chilly reception as if I was being a hypochondriac. About a year later I find out I have breast cancer, was offered a lumpectomy for a 1.7cm tumor. I said, "NO WAY, take them BOTH off" and I had DIEP. It's the best decision I ever made. I understand you have not been diagnosed but sometimes it's best to go with your gut and not listen to others.

Posts.Title: Mourning my breasts pre-mastectomy...A eulogy NanG crystalphm

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 10:09AM nora_az wrote: Hi everyone. Today I am 6 weeks post TC treatments (still on herceptin) and my hair is coming back!  I felt I could now join the ranks here with all you beautiful women! My hair never did fall all the way out, albeit very, very thin. It wasn't even patchy. I had my hair buzzed with a 2 way back in mid December. A lot more fell out after that, what didn't fall out kept growing and I had it buzzed with a 2 again in February. I have to admit what was growing though never looked good. It looked like pubic hair and it was totally gray! Last week I decided to dye it chestnut brown. I put it in my hair, started doing chores around the house, was waiting on the 25 minutes. Never looked at myself in the mirror until around 20 minutes out. I caught a glimpse of myself and it was bright ORANGE!  OMG I ran to the sink and rinsed the heck out of it. Then when it was done I dried it off and because I was basically bald with this bit of hair I looked like a flipping baby orangutan! Now my real hair is growing back under that mess. Thinking of options here and when I should go ahead and buzz off the orangey color.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 09:21PM nora_az wrote: MEEEEEEEEEEEE   at six weeks!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 10:21AM nora_az wrote: I have had a wig for 3 weeks now. I HATE it. It looks very good and real however the minute I get home I rip the thing off my head. My head is very sensitive, I'm thinking that will go away soon? I have a teenage boy and I know he is very sensitive about the issue so I wear it in public when I am with him. The other day I went to Safeway with only a baseball cap on. I must admit it felt very liberating to not give a crap what other's thought.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 08:16AM nora_az wrote: You have no idea how good it is to hear about long term survivors with lymph node involvement. My surgeon was not expecting any lymph node involvement and I had one bad lymph node and something in the lymph node channel which I still don't understand and want more info on. When I woke up I remember the first thing I asked was, "Was it in the lymph nodes?" and when I found out it was even though I was all drugged up my heart sunk. I've been dwelling on this a bit too much the past month or so but your post really helped me. Thanks!
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 02:51PM nora_az wrote: I had a BMX with immediate construction but had issues not with that but during the chemo phase. I normally have thick long hair. It all went away with the chemo. I remember one time my husband asked me to go to a business dinner with him. I found a dress, put it on (I didn't have my wig on) I couldn't find one that didn't show my port. I then really took a good look at myself and there I was with no hair and this stupid port sticking up out of my chest. I just started crying, there was no way anyone could tell me I looked feminine at that moment and I felt so damn ugly.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 11:48PM nora_az wrote: I wont say it's not painful, but I know for me it was the right choice. It was a very hard one to make too! I wasn't looking at the short term. I knew it would be painful and I would need a lot of help. I was looking at a year down the road would I be happy with my decision and feel "complete" The answer is, "YES!" I am so happy I had DIEP. It was one hell of a surgery but it's so worth it once you are healed.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with mastectomy mybodymydecision nora_az

Posts.Content: nora_az wrote: I was starting to type out everything but realized it says it all on my profile so pardon me if I just paste it on here, it says it all. How the heck can I have breast cancer just 9 months after a successful  breast reduction??  I had a breast reduction 8/26/09. Everything was great. Loved my new smaller breasts. Had to have tests beforehand to make sure I didn't have breast cancer which I didn't. They tested all the tissue afterwards, everything was benign. Fast forward to 6/10 just 9 short months later I found a lump in my right breast which I was sure was scar tissue from the breast reduction. I put it off for 2 months then finally saw my doctor. He had me go in for a mammogram and ultrasound. The radiologist called me in her office before I even got dressed to tell me she didn't like the lump and called it "suspicious" This was on 8/26/2010 the one year anniversary of my breast reduction surgery! Had biopsy the next week and was told on 9/03/10 that I have IDC. I am still at the very beginning of all of this and a bit overwhelmed but searching out for more information to educate myself Does this mean it's been in there for a really long time and it was there when I had my reduction surgery? Perhaps this means I have some sort of fast cancer that formed immedately after surgery? I did have the tissue biopsied then.   I'm just really confused on the timing of all of this. DIEP with nipple sparing mastectomy on 10/13/10 TCH started 11/26/10 Anastrozole started 4/7/11 Hysterectomy/ooph and VATS (lung) surgery 5/22/12 diagnosis Coccidioidomycosis, not metastasis to the lungs as they thought. Yeahhh Dx 9/3/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: nora_az wrote: The last time I went to see my oncology doctor I mentioned that I was spotting and hadn't had a real period yet since chemo. She informed me that my treatment may put my body into menopause. I am on the TCH regimine. I was not warned of this beforehand. Do most women go through this if they still have their periods and not ready for menopause prior to treatment?  This waking up every hour and then waking up for good at 4.45am is driving me crazy!  Is there anything I can do?  Do the periods come back after treatment?  Dont get me wrong, the not having a period is great, it's the lack of sleep that I am attributing to it that is really getting to me. I started my period the same age my Mom was and she started menopause in her mid-50's so I always figured I still had quite a few years left before I worried about it. She had breast cancer 9 years ago and they put her on tamoxifen after her chemo. At age 65 she started her period all over again!  She said she could live without that monthly reminder.

Posts.Title: BC found after breast reduction Dee2011 Dee2011

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 03:00AM nora_az wrote: fightinhrd.... Yes, sometimes I wonder if my reduction saved my life. If my breasts were as big as they used to be I probably would've never found this on my own like I did. I was due for a mammogram in May of this year (the last one was May 09) the only reason I didn't do it was because I was so fresh post op and to be honest my breasts are still a bit sore from what they did to them. I was living under the false presumption that since my breasts were ok less than a year ago they were still ok. I have an appointment at the Breast Clinic in Scottsdale at the Mayo Clinic on Thursday. We'll see what the doctor there says. Until then I have so much "stuff" going through my head, nothing no one else hasnt been through who's on here I'm sure! Thanks for replying!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 03:18AM nora_az wrote: I am so happy with my choice of a bilateral DIEP with a nipple sparing mastectomy.  The thought of having to go through "one more surgery" when I am finally done with herceptin and chemo is something I dont have to go through. I was told all I needed was a lumpectomy with radiation to begin with. It was me who opted for the other based off family history.
Posts.Title: I've had both surgeries if you have questions nosurrender nora_az

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 01:43PM nora_az wrote: Mindy, Your feelings are so normal. I worry about my 18 year old high functioning autistic boy on a daily basis and hope everything turns out ok. Do yourself a favor, I learned this from a counsellor, as much as your mind wanders into the worst case scenarios, snap it back and think of positive things. I didn't think it possible but I am able to do it now. Also, the best advice that I was give by my oncologist and breast surgeon is to not dig too deeply into the Internet on your condition and think the info you are getting is all correct. A lot of what's out there for you to read is old stats and there are a lot of treatments now that weren't available back then.
